We were talking about the

this figure on Monday.

And the particular problem that

NaOH.

And that was 0.15 molar.
And you were given the Ka for

been added yet.
Let me just put that down.

We are plotting the volume of

The first step in doing this

added so far.
For the acid, there was 25 mLs originally of

0.15 molar concentration.
So far we have added 0.75x10^-3 moles.
This strong base will react

with the acid.
It will pull off a hydrogen ion, or a proton,

it to its conjugate base.
Now we need to figure out how

much we have left after this
reaction. We had 2.5x10^-3 moles of the
weak acid.

We have now converted over

We have 1.75x10^-3 moles of the

so 0.75x10^-3 moles have been
converted from acid to the conjugate base.
Now we need to know the

molarities of those amounts,
so we take the weak acid, the number of moles divided by
the total volume now,

which is 25 plus the 5 we just
added, or 30 milliliters.

And we have a concentration.
And then we do the same with a weak base, number of moles that
we have divided by the new

volume gives you the molarity.

water problem,

Here, this is really like a buffer problem.

We had come up with the pH of

3.38.
And you have to set up using Ka, check your assumptions and
calculate pH.

There is another way that you

The first part is the same.

You have to do all the

The second part is different.

Instead of setting up that

In this case,
you need to know pKa. And you know Ka.
You take the minus log of Ka to

And then you can fill in your concentration of the weak acid

conjugate base that is formed
after the addition of 5 mLs.

And then you can calculate.
And you should definitely get the same pH out of this 3.38.
Now, this equation,

the Henderson-Hasselbalch
equation, only works with the assumption that x is small,
so that 5% rule that we talked

we are making an assumption.
We are assuming that the initial concentrations that we
have are the same as the

concentrations we have at
equilibrium, which is basically saying x is small.
You can only use it if x is,

in fact, small.
The way that you would check, in this case,
is you have to back calculate.

You know your pH answer,
and then you have to calculate then what the hydronium ion

which is easy because pH just

And so you can get this answer

out.
Then you take this and divide by either of these two.
You want to use really the

smaller one or both of them and
see, is x small? And, in this case,
both of those are less than 5%.

4.2x10^-4 is less than 5% of
this number and of this number, so that assumption is okay.
If it was not okay,

you would have to have used
option one and used the quadratic equation.
If x is not small,

the only way you can do it is
option one with quadratic. But most of the time,
x is small because we are

talking about weak acids and
bases. And a lot of people find the

This is right in the middle of

strong base but it is not changing the pH very much,

buffered.
The pH is staying the same, so it is the flat part of the

half the amount of the strong

base that you need to reach the

base are equal to the number of

Make sure that you remember

point.
Again, the equivalence point, also called the stoichiometric

the amount of strong base,
the moles of strong base, that are equal to the moles of
the weak acid you had to begin

with.
You have converted all of your weak acid to its conjugate.
In terms of the pH,

the pH is going to depend on
the salt that is formed as a result of this addition.
In the case when you are

All you are going to have around is conjugate base,

so you are going to be greater
than 7. In this case,

in the form of a salt and water.
The Na plus doesn't do anything for you.
It has no effect on pH.

All Group 1 and Group 2 have no

greater than 7 at the
equivalence point. And this is a good way to

If you know what kind of

you know you have made some
kind of math mistake somewhere along.
